docs.title: Welcome to CSCI 0500 - Data Structures, Algorithms, and Intractability: An Introduction!
docs.text:
This course will cover the basics of how to design and analyze data structures and algorithms. We will develop algorithmic intuition through rigorous analysis of algorithmic correctness and performance. We will also study the theory of NP-completeness, which helps us understand which problems are computationally intractable.

Lectures: M/W 3–4:20 PM (All lectures will be recorded) Location: see CAB Textbook: Algorithmic Foundations: Data Structures, Algorithms, and Intractability. Philip Klein and Algorithm Design. Kleinberg and Tardos

docs.title: Waitlist Information
docs.text: Please send an override request through CAB. No further action is necessary. Whenever slots are available, codes are sent out in the evening of every workday. Starting during the shopping period, codes that are unredeemed for 24 hours will be revoked.

docs.title: Assignments
docs.text:
Linked here is the cs0500 styling page! Please add this to your overleaf folder for proper compilation :)

docs.title: Lab Schedule
docs.text:
Labs will be held Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Location and Times can be found on the calendar.

# Lab Date 1 Sorting 1/28 – 1/30 2 Writing Proofs 2/4 – 2/6 -- Divide and Conquer Mini-Lab Optional 3 Dynamic Programming 2/18 – 2/20 4 Hashing 2/25 – 2/27 5 Data Structures 3/4 – 3/6 6 Graph Algorithms: Single-Source Shortest Paths 4/1 – 4/3 7 Graph Algorithms: Bipartite Matching 4/8 – 4/10 8 NP-Hard and NP-Complete Problems 4/15 – 4/17

docs.title: Please refer to the calendar to see locations.

Title IX

All Brown University Employees, including Computer Science Department Teaching Assistants, are Title IX Mandatory Reporters We are required to report all violations related to: sexual assault, sexual violence, gender-based discrimination, and pregnancy-related discrimination.
